incidentrule.description: Saves 5 minutes before+after of the buffer if a PurePaths takes over 30 seconds.
Saves 5 minutes before+after of the buffer if a PurePaths contains exceptions.
A prior connected Application Process/Agent was shut down.
Connection to a previously connected Application Process/Agent has been lost.
Raises incidents for individual connected agents.
Session was cleared.
The system profile configuration changed.

Agent automatically disabled its instrumentation. Possible reasons are for example, if there was no Collector reachable when the Agent was started up or overall instrumentation performance on the Collector was too low.

incidentrule.id: High CPU Usage for Application Process
incidentrule.description: Creates an incident when high cpu usage is detected for a longer period.

condition.refmeasure: High CPU Usage for Application Process

incidentrule.id: High GC Activity for Application Process
incidentrule.description: Fires an incident when a high amount of process time is used for garbage collection.

condition.refmeasure: SUD High GC Activity - CPU Utilization
SUD High GC Activity - GC Utilization

incidentrule.id: High Memory Usage for Application Process
incidentrule.description: Memory usage sustained at a high percentage for a longer time period.

condition.refmeasure: High Memory Usage for Application Process

incidentrule.description: Agent disabled CPU time capturing because of too high overhead. Check the agent's CPU time capturing options in the agent group's sensor configuration dialog.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that are corrupted.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that have been truncated as their size exceeds the node limit.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that have timed out as either a method has not returned, or a whole child path did not finish within a certain timeout.
Signals performed agent hot sensor placement
Application Process reported Out-of-memory. A Memory Dump will be automatically triggered if not disabled in the Agent group settings.
Continuous transaction recording was aborted.
A test violation (test has degraded/improved/failed, or is volatile) occurred.
Custom user created Incidents.
The overall failed transaction rate exceeds the configured threshold.

incidentrule.id: High Overall Failed Page Action Rate
incidentrule.description: The overall failed page action rate exceeds the configured threshold.

The average response time (median) is significantly higher than expected. Although the observed response time might be still acceptable for users, this behavior is typically caused by application or infrastructure problems and reduces the maximum throughput you can achieve.

incidentrule.id: Response time degraded for slow requests
incidentrule.description: The observed response time for the slowest 10% of requests has increased significantly. This results in poor user experience and can be caused by application or infrastructure problems.
The rate of failed transactions is significantly higher than expected.
Orderly shutdown of Application Process/Agent.
Custom user created incidents for deployment.

mastermonitorconfig.desc: Reads out PerfMon information from BizTalk, all counters are stored in seperate instances that is called the same name as the BizTalk Hosting Process so the normal Windows Counters can't pull the data out. Eg. default instance is BizTalkServerApplication and is hosted by BTSNTSvc.exe, so {pid} and {monitored_process} doesn't work propperly.

measure.description: The delay injected in each qualifying batch for throttling the publishing of messages.
The number of message publish requests issued by the service class per second.
The number of messages actually published by the service class per second.

The throttling state of the message publishing. A non-zero value indicates that the message publishing is being throttled due to one of the following reasons:
* 0: Not throttling * 2: Throttling due to imbalanced message publishing rate (input rate exceeds output rate) * 4: Throttling due to process memory pressure * 5: Throttling due to system memory pressure * 6: Throttling due to database growth * 8: Throttling due to high session count * 9: Throttling due to high thread count * 11: Throttling due to user override on publishing
Seconds spent in the current state (throttling or not throttling) of message publish throttling.
The user override for the message publishing.
The delay injected in each batch for throttling the delivery of messages.
The number of messages delivered to the service class per second.
The number of messages processed by the service class per second.

The throttling state of the message delivery. A non-zero value indicates that the message delivery is being throttled due to one of the following reasons: 1- rate, 3- unprocessed message, 4- process memory, 5- system memory, 9- thread count, 10- user override.
Seconds spent in the current state (throttling or not throttling) of message delivery throttling.
The user override for the message delivery.
The number of currently opened database sessions exceeds the BizTalk threshold.

The destination queue depth of all messagebox databases exceeds the BizTalk threshold. If the host publishes to multiple queues, the weighted average across all destination queues is computed (based on recent publish statistics) and compared with the BizTalk threshold.
The number of in-process messages exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The message delivery rate is higher than the message processing rate.
The message publishing request rate is higher than the message publishing completion rate.
The process memory consumption exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The system-wide physical memory consumption exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The thread count exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
Number of bytes received by adapter per second.
Number of times file receive adapter failed to lock the file per second.
Number of bytes sent by adapter per second.
Number of messages received by adapter per second.
Number of messages sent by adapter per second.
Number of messages received by adapter per second.
Number of messages sent by adapter per second.

mastermonitorconfig.desc: Reads out PerfMon information from BizTalk, all counters are stored in seperate instances that is called the same name as the BizTalk Hosting Process so the normal Windows Counters can't pull the data out. Eg. default instance is BizTalkServerApplication and is hosted by BTSNTSvc.exe, so {pid} and {monitored_process} doesn't work propperly.

measure.description: The delay injected in each qualifying batch for throttling the publishing of messages.
The number of message publish requests issued by the service class per second.
The number of messages actually published by the service class per second.

The throttling state of the message publishing. A non-zero value indicates that the message publishing is being throttled due to one of the following reasons:
* 0: Not throttling * 2: Throttling due to imbalanced message publishing rate (input rate exceeds output rate) * 4: Throttling due to process memory pressure * 5: Throttling due to system memory pressure * 6: Throttling due to database growth * 8: Throttling due to high session count * 9: Throttling due to high thread count * 11: Throttling due to user override on publishing
Seconds spent in the current state (throttling or not throttling) of message publish throttling.
The user override for the message publishing.
The delay injected in each batch for throttling the delivery of messages.
The number of messages delivered to the service class per second.
The number of messages processed by the service class per second.

The throttling state of the message delivery. A non-zero value indicates that the message delivery is being throttled due to one of the following reasons: 1- rate, 3- unprocessed message, 4- process memory, 5- system memory, 9- thread count, 10- user override.
Seconds spent in the current state (throttling or not throttling) of message delivery throttling.
The user override for the message delivery.
The number of currently opened database sessions exceeds the BizTalk threshold.

The destination queue depth of all messagebox databases exceeds the BizTalk threshold. If the host publishes to multiple queues, the weighted average across all destination queues is computed (based on recent publish statistics) and compared with the BizTalk threshold.
The number of in-process messages exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The message delivery rate is higher than the message processing rate.
The message publishing request rate is higher than the message publishing completion rate.
The process memory consumption exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The system-wide physical memory consumption exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The thread count exceeds the BizTalk threshold.

mastermonitorconfig.desc: Reads out PerfMon information from BizTalk, all counters are stored in seperate instances that is called the same name as the BizTalk Hosting Process so the normal Windows Counters can't pull the data out. Eg. default instance is BizTalkServerApplication and is hosted by BTSNTSvc.exe, so {pid} and {monitored_process} doesn't work propperly.

Seconds spent in the current state (throttling or not throttling) of message publish throttling.
The user override for the message publishing.
The delay injected in each batch for throttling the delivery of messages.
The number of messages delivered to the service class per second.
The number of messages processed by the service class per second.

The throttling state of the message delivery. A non-zero value indicates that the message delivery is being throttled due to one of the following reasons: 1- rate, 3- unprocessed message, 4- process memory, 5- system memory, 9- thread count, 10- user override.
Seconds spent in the current state (throttling or not throttling) of message delivery throttling.
The user override for the message delivery.
The number of currently opened database sessions exceeds the BizTalk threshold.

The destination queue depth of all messagebox databases exceeds the BizTalk threshold. If the host publishes to multiple queues, the weighted average across all destination queues is computed (based on recent publish statistics) and compared with the BizTalk threshold.
The number of in-process messages exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The message delivery rate is higher than the message processing rate.
The message publishing request rate is higher than the message publishing completion rate.
The process memory consumption exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The system-wide physical memory consumption exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
The thread count exceeds the BizTalk threshold.
